ld.headline: The Role of Safe-Haven Assets in Market Turbulence

correlation.name: Correlation Profile
correlation.value: Safe-havens often exhibit low or negative correlation with equities, reducing portfolio volatility in drawdowns.

crisis.name: Crisis Behavior
crisis.value: During risk-off episodes, flows shift toward gold, top-rated sovereign bonds, and select currencies (CHF/JPY).

tradeoffs.name: Trade-offs
tradeoffs.value: Lower expected returns and crowding risk during crises can lead to overvaluation and subsequent reversals.

overview.title: Overview
items: Safe-haven assets are instruments that tend to retain or increase value during periods of market turbulence and uncertainty.
Investors turn to safe-havens to preserve capital, reduce portfolio risk, and cushion volatility when risk assets decline.
They play a key role in diversification and risk management during financial crises, geopolitical events, or recessions.

items.label: Gold:
items.text: A long-standing store of value that often rises during economic instability.

items.label: US Treasury Bonds:
items.text: Considered low risk and backed by the US government; prices typically rise and yields fall in risk-off periods.

items.label: Swiss Franc (CHF):
items.text: Benefits from Switzerland’s stable economy and low inflation, attracting flows in stress episodes.

items.label: Japanese Yen (JPY):
items.text: A classic safe-haven currency supported by Japan’s external balance and deep financial markets.

items.label: Defensive Stocks:
items.text: Sectors like utilities, healthcare, and staples are less cyclical and can provide relative stability.

why.title: Why Investors Turn to Safe-Haven Assets

capital.title: Capital Preservation
items: Safe-haven allocations can limit drawdowns when equities fall sharply.
They help protect purchasing power and portfolio value in turbulent markets.

diversification.title: Portfolio Diversification
items: Low or negative correlations reduce overall portfolio volatility.
Balancing risk assets with safe-havens can smooth returns across cycles.

hedge.title: Hedge Against Inflation and Currency Risks
items: Gold is commonly used to hedge inflation and currency debasement.
Safe-haven currencies (e.g., CHF) can mitigate FX risk in global portfolios.

reactions.title: Market Reactions During Times of Turbulence

demand.title: Increased Demand for Safe-Havens
items: Volatility spikes often trigger flows into gold, Treasuries, and safe-haven FX.
Investors rotate out of cyclicals and risk assets toward perceived safety.

bonds.title: Flight to Quality in Bond Markets
items: Government bond prices typically rise as yields compress in risk-off regimes.
Flight-to-quality underscores the role of sovereign debt as a stabilizer.

benefits.title: Benefits of Including Safe-Haven Assets in a Portfolio
items: Reduces portfolio volatility and mitigates drawdowns.
Provides liquidity and stability during market stress.
Supports long-term resilience across economic cycles.

limits.title: Limitations of Safe-Haven Assets
items: Lower long-run return potential versus growth assets.
Crowding risk can lead to overvaluation during crises.
Not fully immune to price swings as sentiment shifts.
